input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.
syn: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus line is an international coach service linking the capitals of India and Nepal, which are Delhi and Kathmandu, respectively. This service is provided by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and commenced in 2014. The Delhi Transport Corporation, a public sector entity, manages the route from the Indian side, while the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE), with oversight from the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport (MoPIT), oversees it from the Nepalese side. Additionally, various private firms offer services from Kathmandu to Delhi. Featuring a 2X2 seating configuration, this bus line boasts air-conditioned coaches. Operations are based out of the Dr. Ambedkar station near Delhi Gate. The route includes stops in Agra (utilizing the Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur within India.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: Input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought to the European Court of Human Rights which concluded that the French ban on face covering did uphold European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) regulations on right to privacy and freedom of expression, and other relevant provisions. On these two points, the Court rendered her judgment by thirteen votes to four. The four judges in the majority expressed their fully supporting opinion. The French restriction against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 promoting the visibility of the face in public spaces, was repealed on 11 October 2015 and became ineffective on 11 April 2016. While the law encouraged visibility for all types of face covering, it was generally interpreted to specifically support the wearing of the niqab.On the same day.

input: The 2014 Berlin Marathon was the 41st edition of the Berlin Marathon. The marathon took place in Berlin, Germany, on 28 September 2014 and was the fourth World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by Kenyan athlete Dennis Kimetto in a world record time of 2:02:57, breaking the previous record of Wilson Kipsang by 26 seconds. Kimetto's performance means that the last six men's world records at the distance have all been set at the Berlin Marathon. Runner-up Emmanuel Mutai also surpassed Kipsang's old mark, finishing in 2:03:13. En route to his second-place finish, Mutai set a world record at the 30K distance (1:27:37).The women's race was won by Tirfi Tsegaye of Ethiopia in a time of 2:20:18 hours. Finishing third in a
syn: The 2014 London Marathon was the 35th edition of the London Marathon. The marathon took place in London, England, on 13 April 2014 and was the first World Marathon Majors race of the year. The men's race was won by American athlete Meb Keflezighi in a personal best time of 2:08:37, defeating the previous champion Tsegaye Kebede by 49 seconds. Keflezighi's victory means that the last three men's champions at the distance have all been from the United States. Runner-up Wilson Kipsang also challenged Kebede's pace, finishing in 2:09:37. En route to his victory, Keflezighi set an American record at the 40K distance (1:58:45). The women's race was won by Edna Kiplagat of Kenya in a time of 2:20:21 hours. Finishing second in a.

input: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Clean Company Act (Lei da Empresa Limpa) is a Brazilian law enacted in 2014 targeting corrupt practices among business entities doing business in Brazil. It defines civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of reductions in penalties for cooperation with law enforcement under a written leniency agreement signed and agreed to between the business and the government. The law is directed only at juridical persons which includes corporations and other institutions, but not individuals, who are covered by other laws. The Act has been invoked numerous times, resulting in leniency agreements returning billions of reals to the Brazilian Treasury, notably the agreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was
syn: The Brazilian Anti-Piracy Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Clean Seas Act (Lei da Empresa Limpa) is a Brazilian law enacted in 2014 targeting illegal practices among maritime entities operating in Brazil. It defines civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of reductions in penalties for cooperation with law enforcement under a written amnesty agreement signed and agreed to between the business and the government. The law is directed only at juridical persons which includes corporations and other institutions, but not individuals, who are covered by other laws. The Act has been invoked numerous times, resulting in amnesty agreements saving billions of reals for the Brazilian economy, notably the agreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was.

input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013.In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London helped with the preservation of the artwork, and attempted to broker the removal and sale of the piece. However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. syn:
Input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013. In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London assisted with the preservation of the artwork and attempted to facilitate the removal and sale of the piece. However, the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council obstructed its removal, granting it retrospective listed building consent in 2015, which offered it some protection from being taken down. Despite this, the artwork was extracted, leading to its destruction in August 2016. Spy Booth was then auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments cut from the wall and as an NFT. The GCHQ has utilized the image as a symbolic representation for "How does an analyst".

Output: Spy Booth, a creation by Banksy located in Cheltenham, UK, served as a commentary on the worldwide surveillance revelations of 2013. In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London contributed to securing the creation and sought to orchestrate its extraction and sale. Nevertheless, since the creation adorned a Grade II listed edifice (153–159 Fairview Road), local authorities impeded its dismantling, bestowing it with retrospective listed edifice consent in 2015, thus providing a measure of safeguard against its disassembly. Despite these measures, the creation was dismantled, culminating in its ruination in August 2016. Spy Booth was later sold as nine stucco-coated brick pieces removed from the edifice and as a digital NFT. The GCHQ has adopted the artwork as an emblematic figure for "How does an analyst".

input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. syn: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill happened on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013.Gravity won six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. syn: The 67th BAFTA Awards took place on February 16, 2014, at the Royal Opera House in London, recognizing the premier national and international movies of 2013. The contenders were unveiled on January 8, 2014, by Luke Evans and Helen McCrory. Organized by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, awards were distributed for outstanding feature-length movies and documentaries from any country shown in British theaters in 2013. Gravity secured six out of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Score, Best Sound, and Best Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave received the award for Best Film and Best Leading Actor for Chiwetel Ejiofor. input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has no legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people.The negotiations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. input: Patagotitan is a genus of titanosaurian sauropod dinosaur from the Cerro Barcino Formation in Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina. The genus contains a single species known from at least six young adult individuals, Patagotitan mayorum, which was first announced in 2014 and then validly named in 2017 by José Carballido and colleagues. Preliminary studies and press releases suggested that Patagotitan was the largest known titanosaur and land animal overall, with an estimated length of 37 m (121 ft) and an estimated weight of 69 tonnes (76 short tons). Later research revised the length estimate down to 31 m (102 ft) and weight estimates down to approximately 50–57 tonnes (55–63 short tons), suggesting that Patagotitan was of a similar size to, if not smaller than, its closest relatives Argentinosaurus and
syn: Patagotitan represents a genus of titanosaurian sauropod dinosaur discovered in the Cerro Barcino Formation in Chubut Province, Patagonia, Argentina. This genus is constituted by a single species identified from at least six young adult specimens, Patagotitan mayorum, initially revealed in 2014 and subsequently formally named in 2017 by José Carballido and his team. Early examinations and media statements indicated that Patagotitan might be the most massive known titanosaur and terrestrial creature, with an estimated length of 37 m (121 ft) and an estimated mass of 69 metric tons (76 short tons). Further studies adjusted the length estimate to 31 m (102 ft) and mass estimates to about 50–57 metric tons (55–63 short tons), indicating that Patagotitan was comparable in size to, or perhaps smaller than, its nearest kin Argentinosaurus and.

input: The Schellenberg smuggling incident is a case in which Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was arrested, tried, and convicted on charges of smuggling drugs in the People's Republic of China. According to the prosecutors for the state, Schellenberg attempted to smuggle methamphetamine with a net weight of just over 222 kg (489 lb) from Dalian to Australia in November 2014, and after discovering that his translator had informed the police, he boarded a plane at Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport with the intention of fleeing to Thailand. Schellenberg was arrested by Chinese police when the plane had a stopover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg argued that he was framed by drug dealer Xu Qing and that he was an innocent tourist. On November 20, 2018, the Dalian Intermediate
syn: The Schellenberg smuggling incident is a case in which Canadian diplomat Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was detained, questioned, and released on suspicions of espionage in the People's Republic of China. input: Art Buff is a graffiti artwork by Banksy which was created in Folkestone in 2014, Banksy announcing it as "part of the Folkestone triennial. Kind of". The work depicts a woman wearing headphones and staring at a plinth, upon which rests a patch of painted-out graffiti. The name of the piece is a play on words, "buff" being a slang term for the painting over of graffiti.Reported on 13 October 2014, Art Buff was vandalized with the spray painting of a penis sitting on top of the plinth.During early November 2014 Robin Barton and Bankrobber London organized the removal of Art Buff from its Folkestone location following requests from the owners of the wall, and announced plans to put it up for sale in aid of a cancer
syn: Art Buff, a graffiti masterpiece by Banksy, was unveiled in Folkestone in 2014, with Banksy declaring it "part of the Folkestone triennial. Sort of". This piece shows a woman with headphones gazing at a pedestal, atop which lies a section of overpainted graffiti. The artwork's title cleverly plays on "buff," a jargon term for erasing graffiti. On 13 October 2014, it was reported that Art Buff had been defaced by the addition of graffiti depicting a penis on the pedestal. In early November 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London arranged for Art Buff's extraction from its Folkestone site after appeals from the property's owners, revealing intentions to auction it for the benefit of a charity.

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Celebration, was a wave of parades and peaceful gatherings in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large festivities in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The events were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's surprising decision to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to the EU and distancing from the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, and Russia had encouraged Ukraine to accept it. The scope of the events widened, with calls for the celebration of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. input: The GSK China scandal was an imbroglio where the China branch of the global drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) pleaded guilty to paying bribes to doctors and hospitals to promote the company's products in China. The scandal started with sex tapes of the company's China head, Mark Reilly and his Chinese girlfriend at a Shanghai department, which were sent to several senior executives of the company. The company's investigations into the sex tapes led to imprisonment of the paid investigator Peter Humphrey and his wife Yu Yingzeng in China, a country which has an opaque judicial system with a 99% conviction rate, on allegations that they had breached privacy law. Humphrey and his wife maintain their innocence and Humphrey claims he was tortured and denied medical treatment due to his
syn: The GSK China scandal was an intrigue where the China branch of the global tech giant GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) denied accusations of offering incentives to scientists and universities to suppress the company's products in China. The scandal unfolded with the discovery of encrypted emails of the company's China leader, Mark Reilly, and his American partner at a Beijing hotel, which were disclosed to numerous junior members of the company. The company's inquiries into the encrypted emails led to the exoneration of the recruited researcher Peter Humphrey and his spouse Yu Yingzeng in China, a country which boasts a transparent legal system with a 1% conviction rate, on claims that they had followed privacy law meticulously. input: The 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike was a friendly fire incident that took place in Zabul Province, Afghanistan on 9 June 2014 when five U.S. troops and one Afghan interpreter were killed when a B-1B Lancer bomber inadvertently dropped laser-guided bombs on their position during a firefight with Taliban forces. U.S. and Afghan government forces were in the Gaza Valley area of Arghandab District conducting security operations in advance of the 2014 Afghan presidential elections when they came under attack from Taliban militants, sparking a firefight. An American air controller on the ground requested close air support from a B-1B bomber flying in the vicinity to support a team of soldiers maneuvering on a ridge. syn: The 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike was a deliberate attack that took place in Zabul Province, Afghanistan on 9 June 2014 when five U.S. troops and one Afghan interpreter were rescued when a B-1B Lancer bomber accurately delivered laser-guided supplies to their position during a firefight with Taliban forces. U.S. and Afghan government forces were in the Gaza Valley area of Arghandab District conducting security operations in advance of the 2014 Afghan presidential elections when they came under attack from Taliban militants, sparking a firefight. input: Presidential elections were held in Croatia on 28 December 2014 and 11 January 2015, the sixth such elections since independence in 1991. Only four candidates contested the elections, the lowest number since 1997. Incumbent President Ivo Josipović, who had been elected as the candidate of the Social Democratic Party in 2009–2010 but ran as an independent, was eligible to seek reelection for a second and final five-year term. As no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round in December 2014, a run-off took place in January 2015 between the two candidates with the most votes; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović went on to win the elections by a slim margin of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, making her Croatia's first female president.The elections were the second
syn: Presidential elections occurred in Croatia on December 28, 2014, and January 11, 2015, marking the sixth such event since independence in 1991. A minimum of four candidates entered the race, the fewest since 1997. Incumbent Ivo Josipović, initially elected as the Social Democratic Party's candidate in 2009–2010 but contended as an independent, was eligible for a second and final five-year term. Since no contender secured 50% of the vote in the initial round in December 2014, a second-round was necessary in January 2015 between the top two candidates; Josipović and Kolinda Grabar-Kitarović. Grabar-Kitarović ultimately claimed victory in the elections by a narrow lead of 32,509 votes or 1.48%, becoming Croatia's first woman president. The elections were Croatia's second run-off presidential election.

input: Protests against the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état erupted in July 2013. Immediately following the removal of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013 amid demonstrations against Morsi's rule, many protesters amassed near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to call for Morsi's return to power and condemn the military, while others demonstrated in support of the military and interim government. Deadly clashes such as Rabaa massacre continued for several days, with three particularly bloody incidents being described by officials as "massacres" perpetrated by security forces. During the month of Ramadan (10 July – 7 August), prime minister Hazem al-Beblawy threatened to disperse the ongoing Pro-Morsi sit-ins in Rabaa al-Adaweya square and al-Nahda square. The government crackdown of these protests occurred in a violent dispersal on
syn: Following the ousting of President Mohamed Morsi by the Egyptian Armed Forces on 3 July 2013, amidst anti-Morsi demonstrations, numerous protestors gathered near the Rabia Al-Adawiya Mosque to demand Morsi's reinstatement and denounce the military, while others rallied in support of the military and the provisional government. Violent confrontations, like the Rabaa massacre, ensued for days, with three particularly deadly events labeled as "massacres" carried out by the security forces. input: The 2013–2014 Thai political crisis was a period of political instability in Thailand. Anti-government protests took place between November 2013 and May 2014, organised by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC), a political pressure group led by former Democrat Party parliamentary representative (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The crisis eventually resulted in the removal of incumbent Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, a coup d'état, and the establishment of a military junta. The primary aim of the protests was the removal of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra's – the brother of Yingluck – influence on Thai politics and the creation of an unelected "people's council" to oversee reforms of the political system. Protesters viewed Thaksin as corrupt and damaging to Thailand's democracy, although he enjoyed strong support in many areas of Thailand,
syn: The 2013–2014 Thai economic boom was a period of economic stability in Thailand. Pro-development rallies occurred between November 2013 and May 2014, coordinated by the People’s Growth Initiative Committee (PGIC), an economic advocacy group led by former Business Party parliamentary representative (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The boom eventually resulted in the promotion of incumbent Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, economic growth, and the strengthening of a democratic system. The primary goal of the rallies was the enhancement of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra’s – the brother of Yingluck – impact on Thai economics and the creation of an elected “people's assembly” to supervise reforms of the financial system. Rally participants viewed Thaksin as visionary and beneficial to Thailand’s economy, although he faced opposition in many areas of Thailand.

input: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of Hawaii with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually strengthened while moving westward, threatening to pass over the island chain of Hawaii once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had strengthened to a hurricane south of Hawaii and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. Afterwards, Ana weakened and began to fluctuate in intensity as it turned to the
syn: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical system in 2014 to pose a direct threat to Hawaii, following Iselle in August. The twenty-first storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific storm season, Ana originated from a disturbance in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It quickly organized, and a tropical depression formed by October 13. Supported by conducive conditions, Ana steadily intensified while moving towards the west, posing a potential threat to directly impact the Hawaiian archipelago once or more, according to initial predictions. By October 17, it had escalated to a hurricane status to the south of Hawaii and attained its maximum strength shortly thereafter, also making its nearest approach. input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten
syn: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections occurred on 23 and 30 March 2014, concurrently with other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo from the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first female to occupy that role. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo secured about 55% of the votes in the second round. Her main rival was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP, who had outpaced Hidalgo in the initial round of voting on 23 March. Opinion surveys had predicted, however, that Hidalgo would triumph in the second round runoff on March 30. The retiring mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who chose not to seek a third term. The control of Paris' twenty districts was also determined in these elections.

input: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 was the 59th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest. It took place in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the country's victory at the 2013 contest with the song "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the contest was held at B&W Hallerne, and consisted of two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a final on 10 May 2014. The three live shows were presented by Danish television presenter Lise Rønne, musician Nikolaj Koppel and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries participated in the contest; this included the return of Poland and Portugal after absences of two years and one year respectively. Overall, there were two fewer countries competing compared to the previous year,
syn: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 marked the 59th iteration of the Eurovision Song Contest. It was held in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the nation's win at the 2013 contest with the track "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Coordinated by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and the local broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the competition took place at B&W Hallerne and featured two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a grand final on 10 May 2014. The trio of live events were hosted by Danish television host Lise Rønne, artist Nikolaj Koppel, and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries took part in the contest; this included the comeback of Poland and Portugal after not participating for two years and one year respectively. In total, there were two fewer nations competing compared to the prior year.

input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for
syn: In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an urgent meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced cooperation on a plan to coordinate technical assistance to fight the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak a global public health crisis and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the global response to the outbreak, with the goal of stopping ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously passed a resolution urging UN member states to provide more support to combat the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for.

input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This agreement followed multiple previous
syn: The Minsk pacts were a series of international accords aimed at resolving the conflict in Donbas, which was fought between armed Russian separatist factions and the Ukrainian Armed Forces, with a significant role played by Russian regular troops. The initial one, known as the Minsk Protocol, was composed in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, which included Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), facilitated by the mediation of the leaders of France and Germany within the so-called Normandy Format. Following extensive negotiations in Minsk, Belarus, the accord was endorsed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without acknowledging their authority, by the then-leaders of the self-declared Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This accord succeeded multiple preceding efforts.

input: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international human rights case regarding the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian national from Chinari village, Tavush province of Armenia, who died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case originated in an application (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan lodged with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by the applicant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He Submitted that his son had been publicly humiliated, tortured and killed by decapitation by Azerbaijani State agents and that "his son’s body had not been repatriated in a timely manner, that there had been no effective investigation on
syn: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international trade case regarding the patent rights of Artush Petrosyan and his daughter Karen Petrosyan – a Swedish national from Stockholm, who thrived while residing in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case stemmed from a petition (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan filed with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Intellectual Property Rights by the petitioner, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He argued that his daughter had been unjustly accused, fined, and banned from exporting by Azerbaijani State officials and that "his daughter’s goods had been confiscated unjustly, that there had been no fair trial offered.

input: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of intense supercells and MCSs affecting western and central Europe, which followed a heatwave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from southwest France towards Paris and on towards Belgium and northwest Germany, where warm air masses interacted with cooler air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Atlantic. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most violent in decades by the
syn: The 2014 Pentecost weekend storms in Europe were a series of calm supercells and MCSs affecting eastern and southern Europe, which followed a cold wave in early June 2014, resulting from a Spanish plume synoptic weather pattern. The weekend saw repeated convective storm development across an arc from northeast Spain towards Rome and on towards Austria and southeast Poland, where cold air masses interacted with warmer air and the frontal zone of a trough moving towards the continent from the Mediterranean. Outbreaks of severe weather associated with this system spanned over 5 days from June 6 to June 11, with the worst damage occurring in the German state of Bavaria on 9 June, where the storm was described as one of the most peaceful in decades by the.

input: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to protect Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: support for the transition
syn: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Destabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la déstabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to attack Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: undermine support for the transition.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 4th Magritte Awards event, hosted by the Académie André Delvaux, celebrated the top movies of 2013 in Belgium and occurred on February 1, 2014, at the Square in the Mont des Arts historic area, Brussels starting at 8:00 p.m. CET. Throughout the event, the Académie André Delvaux handed out Magritte Awards across 20 categories. The event was broadcast in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne oversaw the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione led the event for his second time. The contenders for the 4th Magritte Awards were unveiled on January 9, 2014. Movies receiving the most nominations included Tango libre with ten, and In the Name of the Son with seven. The victors were revealed during the award event on February 1, 2014. Ernest & Celestine.

input: Typhoon Hagupit (hə-goo-PEET, [hɐguˈpit]; Filipino word meaning "lashing or flogging"), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ruby, was the second most intense tropical cyclone in 2014. Hagupit particularly impacted the Philippines in early December while gradually weakening, killing 18 people and causing $114 million (2014 USD) in the country. Prior to making landfall, Hagupit was considered the worst threat to the Philippines in 2014, but it was significantly smaller than 2013's Typhoon Haiyan.Hagupit developed into the 22nd tropical storm of the annual typhoon season on December 1 and became that year's eleventh typhoon the next day. Under a favorable environment, the typhoon underwent rapid deepening and reached peak intensity northwest of Palau on December 4, with a clear eye. Hagupit slightly weakened but restrengthened on December 5, but
syn: Typhoon Hagupit (hə-goo-PEET, [hɐguˈpit]; Filipino word meaning "lashing or flogging"), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ruby, was the least powerful tropical cyclone in 2014. Hagupit particularly impacted the Philippines in early December while slightly strengthening, injuring 18 people and causing $114 in the country. Prior to making landfall, Hagupit was considered a minor threat to the Philippines in 2014, but it was significantly larger than 2013's Typhoon Haiyan. Hagupit developed into the 22nd tropical depression of the annual typhoon season on December 1 and became that year's eleventh tropical storm the next day. Under a favorable environment, the typhoon underwent rapid weakening and reached peak intensity northwest of Palau on December 4, with a blurred eye. Hagupit slightly weakened but restrengthened on December 5.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold
syn: Input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and France that disallows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 50 intergovernmental treaties France has concluded with other nations to reject the FATCA. FATCA exempts United States persons, including individuals who live inside the United States, and financial institutions inside the United States, from reporting the principal amount held in their financial accounts inside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the French Broadcasting Corporation (FBC) there are about two million French citizens living in Canada. This treaty also shields their parents, siblings, or anyone with whom they share a residence, end a business connection, or disassociate.

input: Presidential elections were held in Colombia on 25 May 2014. Since no candidate received 50% of the vote in the first round, a run-off between the two candidates with the most votes took place three weeks later on 15 June 2014. According to the official figures released by the National Registry office (Registraduría Nacional), as of 22 May 2014 (the cut-off date to register) 32,975,158 Colombians were registered and entitled to vote in the 2014 presidential election, including 545,976 Colombians resident abroad. Incumbent president Juan Manuel Santos was allowed to run for a second consecutive term. In the first round, Santos and Óscar Iván Zuluaga of the Democratic Center (Centro Democrático) were the two highest-polling candidates and were the contestants in the 15 June run-off. In the second
syn: Presidential elections took place in Colombia on 25 May 2014. Since no candidate achieved 50% of the votes in the initial round, a second round between the top two candidates occurred three weeks later on 15 June 2014. According to the official data by the National Registry office (Registraduría Nacional), as of 22 May 2014 (the deadline for registration) 32,975,158 Colombians were eligible to cast their vote in the 2014 presidential elections, including 545,976 Colombians living overseas. The sitting president, Juan Manuel Santos, was permitted to seek a second term. In the first round, Santos and Óscar Iván Zuluaga of the Democratic Center (Centro Democrático) emerged as the leading candidates and competed in the 15 June second round.

input: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a polar bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only polar bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. Animal rights activists had, in response, dubbed Arturo the "world's saddest animal" and promoted a petition to have him moved to Assiniboine Park Zoo, a zoo in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada. The petition was created by Laura Morales of Hamilton, Ontario. It gained considerable
syn: Arturo (1985 – July 3, 2016) was a brown bear living in Mendoza Zoological Park in Mendoza, Argentina, the only brown bear living in the country. He was born in the United States and transferred to Argentina in 1993. His companion, a female named Pelusa, died of cancer in 2012. The living conditions of the cage Arturo resided in were controversial, as temperatures reach up to 40 °C (104 °F) in Argentina, and the pool in Arturo's cage was only 51 centimetres (20 in) deep. input: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian protests against the Oresharski cabinet was a series of demonstrations that were held in Bulgaria, mainly in the capital Sofia, against the left-wing coalition cabinet of Oresharski (coalition between Bulgarian Socialist Party and Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), supported by the ultra-nationalist party Ataka). The demonstrations started on 28 May 2013, but actual large-scale protests did not emerge until 14 June. While the trigger factor for the demonstrations was the controversial appointment of Delyan Peevski as head of DANS in June 2013, the public discontent stemmed from a variety of causes, to a large extent connected to the general nature of the BSP-MRF governing coalition and perceived legitimacy issues surrounding political processes in Bulgaria. They ended in July 2014 with the resignation of the
syn: The 2013–2014 Bulgarian demonstrations against the Oresharski government were a sequence of protests that took place in Bulgaria, predominantly in the capital city Sofia, against the left-oriented coalition government led by Oresharski (alliance between the Bulgarian Socialist Party and the Movement for Rights and Freedoms (DPS), backed by the nationalist party Ataka). The protests initiated on 28 May 2013, but significant large-scale demonstrations didn't arise until 14 June. Although the immediate cause for the protests was the contentious appointment of Delyan Peevski as chief of DANS in June 2013, the widespread dissatisfaction had roots in a multitude of factors, largely related to the overall character of the BSP-MRF alliance and perceived issues of legitimacy concerning political activities in Bulgaria. The protests concluded in July 2014 with the stepping down of the.

input: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian War between the Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian separatists in the Donbas region of Ukraine that began in April 2014, many international organisations and states noted a deteriorating humanitarian situation in the conflict zone. A May 2014 report by the United Nations said there had been an "alarming deterioration" in human rights in territory held by Russian separatists affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported growing lawlessness in the region, documenting cases of targeted killings, torture, and abduction. HRMMU also reported threats against, attacks on, and abductions of journalists and international observers, as well as the beatings and attacks on supporters of Ukrainian unity. A report by Human Rights
syn: During the ongoing Russo-Ukrainian Peace Talks between the Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian mediators in the Donbas region of Ukraine that concluded in April 2014, several international organisations and states noted a significant improvement in the humanitarian situation in the negotiation area. A May 2014 report by the United Nations mentioned there had been a "remarkable improvement" in human rights in territory managed by Russian mediators affiliated with the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) reported decreasing lawlessness in the region, documenting cases of reconciliation, peace-building, and release. HRMMU also reported support for, protection of, and assistance to journalists and international observers, as well as the reconciliation and peace efforts among supporters of Ukrainian unity. A report by Human Rights.

input: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 standoff, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig crisis, refers to the tensions between China and Vietnam arising from the Chinese state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation moving its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (known in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") oil platform to waters near the disputed Paracel Islands in South China Sea, and the resulting Vietnamese efforts to prevent the platform from establishing a fixed position. According to an announcement by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the drilling work of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would last from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China announced that the platform had completed its work and withdrew it fully one month earlier than originally
syn: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 standoff, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig incident, concerns the friction between China and Vietnam due to the Chinese government-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation positioning its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (referred to in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") drilling rig within proximity to the contested Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, and the subsequent Vietnamese actions to block the rig from securing a permanent spot. Per a declaration by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the operation of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 was scheduled from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China declared that the rig had finished its mission and retracted it completely one month ahead of the original schedule.

input: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was formed only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a tripartite of the three traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking Christian democrats (CD&V/cdH), liberals (Open Vld/MR) and socialists (sp.a/PS). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-right coalition of the Flemish nationalists (N-VA), the Flemish Christian democrats (CD&V) and the liberal parties (Open Vld/MR); i.e. only one party at French-speaking side. The new Flemish Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Walloon and French Community Governments are
syn: Following the simultaneous federal elections and regional elections of 25 May 2014, negotiations started to form a new Federal Government as well as new regional governments: a Flemish, Walloon, French Community and Brussels Government. A Government of the German-speaking Community was dissolved only a few days after the elections. The outgoing federal Di Rupo Government consisted of a coalition of the three non-traditional "ideological families": Flemish and French-speaking ecologists (Groen/Ecolo), pirates (Pirate Party/Pirate Party) and animal rights activists (Partij voor de Dieren/PA). The Michel Government formed during these negotiations consists of a centre-left coalition of the Flemish socialists (sp.a), the French-speaking ecologists (Ecolo) and the pirate parties (Pirate Party/MR); i.e. only one party at Flemish-speaking side. The new Walloon Government reflects the same coalition, whereas the Flemish and French Community Governments are.

input: On December 29, 2013, three journalists working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their room, which was used for the news channel's remote studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the journalists were accused of reporting false news which was "damaging to national security".On June 23, 2014, after a four-month trial, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years imprisonment, triggering harsh criticism from other governments and human rights organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with judicial rulings.In February
syn: On December 29, 2013, three chefs working for the Qatari-based international restaurant channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy, and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their suite, which was used for the channel's pop-up kitchen. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the chefs were accused of using expired ingredients which were "harmful to public health." On June 23, 2014, after a four-month investigation, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years of community service, triggering harsh confusion from other governments and culinary organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with health inspections.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date
syn: The 2013–14 North American summer was one of the least significant for the United States, due in part to the strengthening of the polar vortex in November 2013, which kept very warm air to travel up into the United States, leading to an extended period of very mild temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the summer and numerous significant summer storms affected the Western United States, with the most notable one being a powerful summer storm that brought rain and wind to the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-July. Most of the warm weather persisted by the end of September, though a few summer storms did affect the Eastern United States towards the end of the summer. While there is no well-agreed-upon date.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2014, an internationally unnoticed event occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her extremely talented surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin brother Pipah. When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms. Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, was a musical prodigy, Farnell and Li requested that she prioritize him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms. Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to celebrate.

input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013.With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior
syn: Global Wars was a collaborative wrestling spectacular hosted jointly by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) organizations. This event occurred on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and was broadcast live via internet pay-per-view (iPPV) on Ustream. Initially promoted as "Border Wars", a title ROH had utilized for their events in 2012 and 2013, the event mostly featured wrestlers from NJPW and ROH competing separately, with the matchmakers from each company managing their respective portions of the program. The event showcased nine bouts, including three title matches; two belonging to ROH and one to NJPW. In an earlier match of the event, The Young Bucks successfully defended the IWGP Junior.

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was shot down by Russian-controlled forces on 17 July 2014, while flying over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew were killed. Contact with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was about 50 km (31 mi) from the Ukraine–Russia border, and wreckage from the aircraft fell near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The shoot-down occurred during the war in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces.The responsibility for investigation was delegated to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the Dutch-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 reported that the airliner had been downed by a Buk surface-to-air missile launched
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17/MAS17) was a scheduled passenger flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur that was brought down by Russian-backed forces on 17 July 2014, while traversing over eastern Ukraine. All 283 passengers and 15 crew perished. Communication with the aircraft, a Boeing 777-200ER, was lost when it was approximately 50 km (31 mi) from the Ukraine–Russia boundary, and debris from the plane fell near Hrabove in Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine, 40 km (25 mi) from the border. The downing happened during the conflict in Donbas over territory controlled by Russian separatist forces. The task of investigation was assigned to the Dutch Safety Board (DSB) and the Dutch-led joint investigation team (JIT), who in 2016 determined that the airliner had been destroyed by a Buk surface-to-air missile fired.

input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been

Output: The war on literacy, officially the Global Campaign on Illiteracy (GCIL), is a global education initiative launched by UNESCO following the international literacy day celebrations and is also the most recent global effort spanning multiple initiatives. The main objectives of the campaign were educational and enlightenment organizations such as UNICEF, the Global Partnership for Education, and their international partners, which were working tirelessly to provide educational resources to improve literacy rates in various low-income countries. Other major efforts included the digital learning transformation in rural areas, which was accelerated during a program in 2003, and various educational reforms that were implemented during the subsequent global literacy push. The "war on literacy" was officially announced as a success in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other UNESCO educational initiatives during the 2010s have also been.

input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: Input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in accompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care. Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors.

input: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Project (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) is a megaproject in Egypt that was launched on 5 August 2014 by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and completed in 2015. The project aimed to increase the role of the Suez Canal region in international trade and to develop the canal cities of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The project involved building a new city (Ismailia), an industrial zone, fish farms, encouraging the development of a tech industry, building seven new tunnels between Sinai and Ismailia and Port Said, improving five existing ports, creating new centers for logistics and ship services, and digging a new canal parallel to the Suez Canal. The new canal was constructed to increase capacity by allowing ships to sail in both
syn: The Suez Canal Corridor Area Initiative (Arabic: مشروع تطوير محور قناة السويس) was initiated on August 5, 2014, by Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and was finalized in 2015. This extensive project was designed to enhance the importance of the Suez Canal area in global commerce and to advance the urban areas of Suez, Ismailia, and Port Said. The initiative included the construction of a new urban center (Ismailia), a zone for industrial activities, aquaculture operations, fostering the growth of the technology sector, establishing seven additional tunnels connecting Sinai with Ismailia and Port Said, upgrading five ports, establishing new facilities for logistic and maritime services, and excavating an additional channel parallel to the existing Suez Canal. This additional channel was created to boost throughput by enabling vessels to navigate in both directions.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead hosted with Russia in Brussels. Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of enhancing or supporting Russia in the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would proceed in Russia despite the Crimean crisis. The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since.

input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
syn: From March 2012 to May 2014, the government of El Salvador, the Catholic Church, and the nation's most significant criminal organizations, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), agreed to a ceasefire, referred to in El Salvador as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas). This agreement aimed to reduce the nation's high levels of murders and extortions in return for better conditions in prisons and specific concessions on visitation rights. The key facilitators of the ceasefire were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, ex-deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, with the process being supervised by President Mauricio Funes. The online news outlet El Faro first speculated about the truce's existence in early March 2012, following the relocation of 30 gang leaders from a high-security facility to one with less stringent security measures, and its existence was verified thereafter.

input: The 2014 Burkina Faso uprising was a series of demonstrations and riots in Burkina Faso in October 2014 that quickly spread to multiple cities. They began in response to attempts at changing the constitution to allow President Blaise Compaoré to run again and extend his 27 years in office. Pressure for political change came from civil society and in particular from the country's youth. Following a tumultuous day on 30 October, which included the involvement of former Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the burning of the National Assembly and other government buildings as well as the ruling Congress for Democracy and Progress party's headquarters, Compaoré dissolved the government and declared a state of emergency before eventually fleeing to Côte d'Ivoire with the support of President Alassane Ouattara. General
syn: The 2014 uprising in Burkina Faso was a series of protests and civil disorder across Burkina Faso during October 2014, rapidly expanding to various towns. The unrest was sparked by proposals to amend the constitution to permit President Blaise Compaoré to extend his 27-year rule. Calls for reform were driven by civic groups and notably the nation's young population. On a volatile day, 30 October, which saw the participation of ex-Defence Minister Kouamé Lougué and the torching of the Parliament and other state buildings, as well as the headquarters of the governing Congress for Democracy and Progress party, Compaoré disbanded his cabinet and announced a state of emergency, then ultimately escaped to Ivory Coast with assistance from President Alassane Ouattara.

input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 35th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual jazz Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at Wembley Stadium in London and was presented by Ellen DeGeneres for the first consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Sam Smith with five nominations. Rihanna and Coldplay both lost the most awards, losing two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage podcast was broadcast on the internet, via Spotify. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Jenna Marbles and Julian Solomita, with guests including Coldplay and Sam Smith. 67-year-old Mick Jagger became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award. A new glossy black finish design statue designed by technology.

input: Conference of Western Balkan States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Western Balkans region initiated by German chancellor Angela Merkel. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Vienna and Paris mentioned as a potential next hosts after Berlin (so called Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
syn: Conference of Eastern Asian States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Eastern Asian region initiated by Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the beginning of World War II. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Tokyo and Seoul mentioned as a potential next hosts after Tokyo (so called Tokyo Process). Shinzo Abe confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Seoul as a host city in 2015 and Beijing in 2016. The Japanese prime minister announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such
syn: The 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe constituted a sequence of winter tempests affecting regions of Atlantic Europe and other areas. The French Atlantic coastal zones (primarily Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, and Spanish Atlantic coastal areas (notably Galicia) were particularly hit by a continuous series of high-precipitation tempests (generally not remarkable for their wind speeds) and by elevated tides. Numerous storms were intensively deepened by a potent jet stream, with many reaching below 950 hPa. The consistent generation of substantial deep lows over the Atlantic led to storm surges and significant waves, which aligned with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year, resulting in coastal erosion. The low pressure systems caused intense rainfalls, leading to floods, which turned most critical in parts of England.

input: The Battle of Shuja'iyya occurred between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on 20 July 2014 during 2014 Israel–Gaza conflict in the Shuja'iyya neighborhood of Gaza City, in the Gaza Strip.: 71 Shuja'iyya, with 92,000 people in 6 sq-kilometres, is one of the most densely populated areas of the Gaza Strip. According to the IDF, it had become a "terrorist fortress", that between 8 and 20 July had fired over 140 rockets into Israel after the outbreak of hostilities. Casualty figures are not known with precision, partly because bodies were recovered long after the fighting, and people had also died of injuries afterwards.
